projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Yearly Intelligencer; OR A PERFECT CHRONOLOGY: OF ALL The Battailes, Sieges, Conflicts, Actions, Exploits, and all other Signal and Remarkable Pa≈øsages, which have happ'ned in the World.
From September the 29th. 1671. to September the 29th. 1672.
Collected by William Andrevvs, Student in ASTROLOGY.
LONDON, Printed by E. Crowch, for T. Vere, at the Angel without New-gate. 1672.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: YOu have here pre≈øented unto publick view, an Annual Chronology: or a Particular Account, in a Chronological way, of all the mo≈øt material Actions and Pa≈ø≈øages, &c which have happ'ned in mo≈øt Parts of the World, for one whole Year la≈øt pa≈øt; which we hope will prove acceptable unto you.

The work it ≈øelf, I pre≈øume, may not only be u≈øeful and nece≈ø≈øary, but al≈øo very delectable unto many; there being therein clearly ≈øet down, not only what publick matters have happened in the ≈øaid Year past, in His Maje≈øties Dominions: but al≈øo even in all, or mo≈øt parts of the Inhabitable World: diligently Collected from the publick Writings of others, and from ≈øuch Informations as are unque≈øtionable.

What either through the Printers, or my own Inadvertency, hath therein happened Erroneous, we be≈øeech you to pardon: Con≈øidering there are, and will be mi≈øtakes and defects in the be≈øt of Humane Actions: However, I have been as careful in my Collections as po≈ø≈øible, and I hope the Printer and Corrector will be as careful in what belongs unto them, concerning it, in the Printing and Correcting thereof.

If this pre≈øent Chronology, ≈øhall find your kind acceptance, it may animate me hereafter (Deo permittente) to carry on from Year, to Year, the like for the future: And none ≈øhall more oblige me, then ≈øuch, as ≈øhall for time to come, give me real and true Information, of any material matters, &c. which ≈øhall hereafter happen: warrantable for their entry. In the interim, I remain,

closer.signed: Your very humble Servant. William Andrews.
closer.dateline: Radwinter, near Saffron-Walden in E≈ø≈øex, Octob. 31. 1672.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THe Letters N. S. in the ≈øeveral Columns of the Days of every Month, ≈øignifie Stilo Novo, New Stile, or the Foraign Account.

div.head: THE Yearly Intelligencer; OR A PERFECT CHRONOLOGY: OF ALL The Battailes, Sieges, Conflicts, Actions, Exploits, and all other Signal and Remarkable Pa≈ø≈øages, which have happened in the World. From September the 29th. 2671. to September the 29th. 1672.
September. 1671
div.p: THeir Maje≈øties dined at Sir John Hubbarts Hou≈øe at Bleching: after dinner his Maje≈øty parted to Sir Robert Pa≈øtons at Oxney: and her Maje≈øty returned to Norwich.
Sir George Waterman was cho≈øen Lord Mayor of the City of London for the en≈øuing year; and Alderman Jonathan Dawes, and Alderman Robert Clayton, were ≈øworn Sheriffs of London and Middle≈øex,

Their Maje≈øties dined at Sir Robert Pa≈øtons at Oxney: after which his Maje≈øty, together with his Royal Highne≈øs, parted thence to the Lord Towne≈øends at Raynham, and arrived there at night, and her Maje≈øty returned again to Norwich.
Her „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ removed from the Lord Henry Howards at Norwich, for En≈øton, where her Maje≈øty lodged this night.
Doctor Henry Bridgeman, was in the Quire of the Cathedral Church of Che≈øter, con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Soder and Man.
His Maje≈øty parted from the Lord Towne≈øends at Raynham, and arrived at Newmarket.
Her Maje≈øty parted from En≈øton, and arrived and lodged at Audleyend this night.

His Maje≈øty honoured the Univer≈øity and Town of Cambridge with his Royal pre≈øence, attended by many of the Nobility from Newmarket; conferred at Cambridge the Honour of Knight-hood upon Charles Cae≈øar E≈øq, Son of Sir Henry Cae≈øar, and in the evening returned again to Newmarket.

A ≈øharp di≈øpute happ'ned about the I≈øles of Bayon, between the Swallow, a Merchant-Man, Engli≈øh built, Captain John Baddi≈ø≈øon Commander, and an Algerine Pirate, in which the Captain was ≈øhot in the Cheek, his Boat-≈øwain, and two others killed, the Carpenter and fourteen more dangerou≈øly wounded: yet by the courage of the ≈øaid Captain, the Ve≈ø≈øel was ≈øaved from the Turks.
Happ'ned a mo≈øt violent ≈øtorm at Falmouth: in which ≈øome Ve≈ø≈øels were lo≈øt, and many driven a≈øhore.
Certain news from Dublin, of the ≈øafe arrival of the Lord Berkely, (Lord Lieutenant of that Kingdom) there.
Dyed in Child-bed rhe Dutche≈øs d'O≈ø≈øuna, N.S. wife to the Governour of Milan.

div.head: October.
div.p: The King of Danemark in≈øtituted a new Order of Knight-hood, under the name of the Danne Broge, (or the Dani≈øh Colours) and Created twenty four Knights, in remembrance of a great Battel given heretofore, by Woldemar the ≈øecond King of Danemark, again≈øt the Swedes: upon the ≈øight (as is ≈øaid) of the Dani≈øh Colours di≈øplayed in the Heavens, &c.
The Queen of Danemark was delivered of a young Prince.
His Maje≈øty and the Court returned to Whitehall from Newmarket.

Arrived at Plimouth the flying Falcon of Am≈øterdam, from whence ≈øhe went the fir≈øt of January 1669. upon Di≈øcovery, the Ma≈øter whereof affirmed, that he was 50. degrees Southward, that he made the main Land, and di≈øcovered two I≈ølands in the South Sea: on which were men of an extraordinary Stature, being eleven foot in height and all hairy, that he ≈øailed out and home 12900 Dutch leagues.
Captain Baddi≈ø≈øon with the Swallow arrived in the Downs.

Was fought a Duel at the Hague at night by Torch-light,N.S. between the Heer vander Myle, and the Count de Warfu≈øe, on the one ≈øide, and the Counts de Donah, two Brothers on the other, in which the Heer vander Myle was de≈øperately wounded.

Captain Baddi≈ø≈øon came to London, and was pre≈øented to his Royal Highne≈øs, and by his Royal Highne≈øs to his Maje≈øty, who was plea≈øed to order him a gold Chain and Meddal, for his great valour and courage, in ≈øaving the Swallow from the Algerin Pirates.
Sir Robert Southwell, his Maje≈øties Envoy Extraordinary to the Count de Montery, took leave of his Maje≈øty, in order to his Journey to Bru≈ø≈øels.

Their Maje≈øties dined at the Lord Mayors Fea≈øt at Guildhall London, as al≈øo his Royal Highne≈øs, and his Highne≈øs Prince Rupert, &c. where his Maje≈øty, conferred the honour of Knight-hood upon Jonathan Dawes, and Robert Clayton E≈øquires Sheriffs of the City.

div.head: November.
div.p: The States General of the United Provinces, N.S. by a Placaet, forbad all per≈øons what≈øoever within the Territories of the ≈øeven Provinces, to import any French Wines, Vinegar, Canvas, Paper, or Che≈ønuts, &c. upon forfeiture of the ≈øame, &c.
Being her Maje≈øties Birth-day, was ≈øolemnized with the u≈øual expre≈ø≈øions of publick joy.
Dyed at Paris Julie Lucine d'Angene≈øs, N.S. Dutche≈øs of Montan≈øier, in the 64. year of her age.
Was Married by a Proxy at Metz the Prince≈øs Palatine (daughter to the Elector Palatine) to the Duke of Orleans. N.S.

Mon≈øieur Lindenow Envoy for the King of Danemark, in an Audience, acquainted their Maje≈øties with the Birth of the Prince of Danemark; and at the Lady Williams Hou≈øe, in the Palace-yard We≈øtmin≈øter (entertained ≈øeveral) of the Nobility, &c. at a very noble Supper, with other demon≈øtrations of joy.
Arrived at Bru≈ø≈øels Sir Robert Southwell Envoy Extraordinary of his Maje≈øty of Great Britain. N.S.
Letters from Sir Edward Spragge dated September 30. N. S. in Algiers-Bay, ≈øignifying great di≈øorders there: and an alteration of Government among tho≈øe people.
Sir Robert Southwell had Audience of the Count de Montery at Bru≈ø≈øels. N.S.
The Earl of Sunderland, his Maje≈øty's Extraordinary Emba≈ø≈øador to the Crown of Spain, went to Dover in order to his journey for Spain.
His Excellency Don Franci≈øco de Melo, Emba≈ø≈øador from the Crown of Portugal, made his publick entry at London.

div.head: December.
div.p: His Excellency Don Franci≈øco de Melo, Emba≈ø≈øador from the Crown of Portugal, had his publick Audience of their Maje≈øties, and afterwards of his Royal Highne≈øs.
Sir George Downing, his Maje≈øties Emba≈ø≈øador to the States General of the United Provinces, began his journey for Holland.
The City of A≈øtracan was ≈øurrendred to the Commander in chief of the Czars Forces.
Dyed the Lady Katherine, his Royal Highne≈øs's younge≈øt daughter, being about ten Months old.
Was privately Interred in King Henry the 7th. Chappel.
Dyed his Grace William Duke of Somer≈øet, in the 20th. year of his age, leaving his Uncle, the Lord John Seymour Heir of his Honour and E≈øtate.

The new Church, now called Christ Church, near Paris Garden in Southwark, built by John Mar≈øhal late Inhabitant there, was Con≈øecrated by the Right Reverend
Father in God, the Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter.
A Proclamation concerning St. Chri≈øtophers, relating to ≈øome matters there acted by Sir Charles Wheeler, touching the former Inhabitants, and Proprietors in that I≈øland, &c.
Certain news of an Agreement made by the Elector of Cologne and that City.
Sir George Downing, his Maje≈øties Emba≈ø≈øador to the States General of the United Provinces arrived at the Hague. N.S.

div.head: Ianuary.
div.p: Ralph Montague E≈øq was ≈øworn one of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt honourable privy Councel, and took his place accordingly.
Several accidents of fire happened at Venice, which did ≈øome con≈øiderable dammage.
Sir George Downing Emba≈ø≈øador from his Maje≈øty of Great Britain, N.S. had his publick Audience of the States General of the United Provinces.
Was appointed for the Interchanging of the Ratifications of the Treaty,N.S. between the Elector of Cologne and that City.

A Proclamation for the calling home all Marriners, and Sea-faring Men, out of the ≈øervice of Forain Princes and States, and prohibiting their entering thereinto for the future, without Licen≈øe fir≈øt had and obtained.
Certain news of the arrival of a very con≈øiderable body, both of Hor≈øe and Foot of the French Forces, in the Electorate of Cologne.
Dyed the Right Reverend Father in God John Co≈øin, Lord Bi≈øhop of Durham, and Count Palatine there, in the 77. year of his age.
A publick fa≈øt was held in the United Provinces, by the command of the States General, for the averting tho≈øe evils, which ≈øeemed to threaten them from abroad.
Certain news from Captain Hart, from aboard the Rupert Frigat in Aligant Road, of Sir Edward Spragges having concluded an honourable and advantageous Peace with Argiers.
Mr. Jo≈øeph William≈øon ≈øworn Clerck of the Councel in Ordinary, and his Maje≈øty conferred on him the honour of Knight-hood.

div.head: February.
div.p: The heart of the Prince≈øs de Conti, N.S. being embalmed and inclo≈øed in a Box of Silver, was carried to the great Convent of the Carmelites, where it was received with the u≈øual ≈øolemnities.
Sir George Downing his Maje≈øties Emba≈ø≈øador at the Hague, arrived at Whitehall.
Sent Pri≈øoner to the Tower.

The Empre≈øs of Germany was brought to Bed of a Daughter in the Morning,N.S. which was Chri≈øtned in the Evening by the Popes Nuncio, by the name of Maria, Anna, Apolonia, Jo≈øepha, Antonia, Schola≈øtica.
Was Con≈øecrated in the Abby of We≈øtmin≈øter Doctor Guy Carleton Bi≈øhop of Bristol, by his Grace the Arch-bi≈øhop of York.

His Maje≈øty Con≈øtituted Sir Gilbert Gerrad Knight and Baronet,
High Sheriff of the County Palatine of Durham, and appointed Sir Francis Goodrick Temporal Chancellor of the ≈øaid County: to be Keeper of the Great Seal of the ≈øaid Bi≈øhoprick and County Palatine of Durham.
Dyed Sir Thomas Ingram, at his hou≈øe at Thi≈øtleworth.

His Maje≈øty made choice of Sir Robert Carr Knight and Baronet, to ≈øucceed Sir Thomas Ingram, as Chancellor of the County Palatine, and Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, and Keeper of the Seals of the ≈øame: who was thereupon ≈øworn of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt Honourable Privy Councel, and took his place accordingly.
The Marquis d'A≈øtorgas, the new Vice Roy at Naples, N.S. took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of that Government.
Was put to death in Spain Don Jayme de ca≈øtel Blanca, N.S. a Nobleman, Sentenced thereunto by the Royal Councel there, for many enormous crimes, by him committed for 40. years together.
Dyed at Vienna the young Emperial Prince≈øs.N.S.
Dyed Thomas Lord Leigh in the 77. year of his Age, leaving his Grand-child Thomas now Lord Leigh, Heir to his Honour and E≈øtate.
The young Emperial Prince≈øs was privately Interred in the Capucins Church at Vienna. N.S.
A fire at Am≈øterdam.
N.S.The States General of the united Provinces, conferred on his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, N.S. the Commander of Captain General, and Admiral of their Land and Sea Forces.
His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, N.S. entertained the States of Holland at a very noble and ≈øplendid Fea≈øt, in the great Hall, where the ≈øaid States u≈øually a≈ø≈øembled.

The Count de Donah by a Court of Ju≈øtice in Holland, N.S. ≈øentenced to loo≈øe his Command, he had in the ≈øervice of that State, and his goods within tho≈øe Dominions to be confi≈øcated, for killing in a Duel Mon≈øieur vander Myle.

His Maje≈øty honoured the Reader of Lincolns-Inn Sir Francis Goodrick, with his pre≈øence at dinner, accompanyed with his Royal Highne≈øs, and his Highne≈øs Prince Rupert, conferred there the honour of Knighthood upon Mr. Pedley, and Mr. Stote, two former Readers there: as al≈øo upon Mr. James Butler, and Mr. Francis Dorrel, of the ≈øame Society.

div.head: March.
div.p: Dyed at St. Germans Madam Marie There≈øe of France, N.S. in the fifth year of her Age.

His Maje≈øty in Councel declared and ordered, that it ≈øhould be lawful for any of his Subjects, having a Pa≈øs from his Royal Highne≈øs the Duke of York, Lord High Admiral of England, &c. to Sail and Navigate their Ships with one third of their Seamen and Marriners, being Foraigners, without any hinderance or mole≈øtation, &c.
A ≈øharp Sea-fight began in the afternoon, between ≈øome of his Maje≈øties Frigats, nigh the I≈øle of Wight, and the Dutch Smirna Fleet, which continued till night.

The fight began again, continued all day, in the evening five
of the Dutch riche≈øt Merchant Men were taken, and their Ree Admiral borded by Captain John Holmes in the Gloce≈øter Frigat, who took her, which afterwards ≈øunk in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Captain de Haes, Admiral of this Dutch Smirna Fleet, was killed in this Engagement.

His Maje≈øty with the advice of his Privy Councel, i≈ø≈øued a Declaration for the maintaining of the Church of England, in its Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, and Government, as it is e≈øtabli≈øhed, and for indulging of Non-conformi≈øts, and di≈ø≈øenting per≈øons in matters of Religion.
His Maje≈øty in Councel gave order for the publi≈øhing of his Declaration of War again≈øt the States General of the United Provinces.

And al≈øo ordered his Proclamation to be i≈ø≈øued for a general fa≈øt, throughout this Kingdom, for the imploring the ble≈ø≈øing of Almighty God, on his Maje≈øties Naval Forces, to be kept in London and We≈øtmin≈øter, &c. on Wedne≈øday the 27th of this Month, and throughout the re≈øt of the Kingdom, on Wedne≈øday after Ea≈øter week.
Sir Edward Spragge, late Admiral of his Maje≈øties Fleet in the Mediterranean, arrived at Whitehall.
The Marquis de Valparacio was ≈øhot at Madrid, N.S. by an unhappy accident, which fell out between the Carpenters of that place, and the Marquis's Gentlemen

Difference aro≈øe at Bru≈ø≈øels, between the Magi≈øtrates and the Commonalty, at a Meeting there of the Commonalty,N.S. call'd the nine Nations, about giving their con≈øent for the rai≈øing of 300000 Florins more, &c.
His Maje≈øty accompanied with his Highne≈øs Prince Rupert went to Chattam, whether his Royal Highne≈øs went before early this morning.

In E≈ø≈øex, between 5 and 6. of the Clock after Noon, was ≈øeen to the Southward of the Sun, and at a pretty di≈øtance from him, an unu≈øual appearance of a Rainbow colour, giving a light re≈øembling that of the Sun, (which was then to be ≈øeen) which ≈øeemed to be a Mock-Sun, the fourth of this Month in the morning, 'twas ≈øeen before though not ≈øo plainly.
The Heer Grotius Emba≈ø≈øador from the States General of the United Provinces, N.S. had his la≈øt Audience of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty at Ver≈øailles.

News of the continuation of the great ≈øcarcity of Corn at Naples, Palermo, Zant, Cephalonia, and Corfu, &c. to the great di≈øtraction of tho≈øe places, &c. and that at I≈ø ‚Ä¢ hia, an I≈øland lying about 150. miles from Naples, the Inhabitants had been ≈øeveral days without bread.
The fa≈øt was ≈øolemnly kept in the Cities of London and We≈øt-min≈øter.
Arrived at Cologne the Count of Hohenfelt, N.S. with the Emperors Ratification of the Treaty concluded by that Elector and that Town.
War was proclaimed again≈øt the States General of the United Provinces in London and We≈øt-min≈øter.

A Proclamation relating to Seamen and Mariners, having left their
ordinary and u≈øual places of abode, &c.
Another Proclamation for calling home all per≈øons of his Maje≈øties Subjects, living in the ≈øervice, &c. of the States General of the United Provinces.

div.head: April.
div.p: Dyed at Paris Madam Marguirette de Lorraine, N.S. Dutche≈øs Dowager of Orleans, in the 57. year of her Age.
The Deputies of the States of Britain had Audience of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty,N.S. about ≈øome matters relating to their Province.
The body of the Dutche≈øs Dowager of Orleans, N.S. was conveyed to St. Dennis, where 'twas Interred with the u≈øual ≈øolemnities.
A Proclamation for the better clen≈øing of the ≈øtreets in We≈øtmin≈øter, and other adjacent places in the County of Middle≈øex.
Was publi≈øhed at Paris the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Kings Declaration of War again≈øt the States General of the United Provinces. N.S.
Mon≈øieur Durant, a French Captain of Hor≈øe in the ≈øervice of the States of Holland, N.S. was by their order taken into cu≈øtody.
Arrived at the Hague the Heer Meerman, N.S. Extraordinary Emba≈ø≈øador of the States General of the United Provinces, to his Maje≈øty of Great Britain.
He made his report in the A≈ø≈øembly of the States General,N.S. and afterwards in that of the Councel of State.
Was publi≈øhed a Manife≈øto of the Elector of Cologne, N.S. wherein he declared to be Neuter, during the war between his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, and the States General of the United Provinces.
A Proclamation for recalling and making void all Protections what≈øoever, before granted to any Seamen or Marriners, ≈øerving in any Merchants Ships, &c.
The Marquis del Fr ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ o Emba≈ø≈øador Extraordinary, from his mo≈øt Catholick Maje≈øty to his Maje≈øty of Great Britain, made his publick Entry at London.
The Heer de Groot late Emba≈ø≈øador of the States General of the United Provinces at the Court of France, N.S. arrived at the Hague.

Happened an Earth-quake at Venice, N.S. and at ≈øome other places, as at Rimini, Pe≈øaro, Ce≈øen, &c. where it appeared violent; e≈øpecially at Rimini, where (as was reported) many of the Inhabitants were killed, and mo≈øt of the Hou≈øes ruined, with one of the principal Churches, and the Bi≈øhop and Clergy of the Place, &c. killed in the ≈øame thereby.
The Marquis del Fre≈øno Emba≈ø≈øador Extraordinary from his mo≈øt Catholick Maje≈øty had his publick Audience of their Maje≈øties, and afterwards of his Royal Highne≈øs.

The two Hou≈øes of Parliament met at We≈øtmin≈øter, according to their former Prorogation of the 22. of April 1671. And further prorogued, in pur≈øuance of his Maje≈øties Proclamation of the 22. of September la≈øt, till the 30. of October 1672.

Was Created the right Honourable John Earl of Lauderdail, Duke of Lauderdale; Henry Lord Arlington, Earl of Arlington, and
Vi≈øcount Thetford; Anthony Lord A≈øhly, Earl of Shaftsbury, and Baron Cooper, &c. and Sir Thomas Clifford, Baron Clifford of Chudleigh.
The Right Honourable Henry, Marquis of Worce≈øter, Arthur Earl of E≈ø≈øex, George Vi≈øcount Hallifax, were ≈øworn of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt honourable Privy Councel, and took their places accordingly.
His Grace the Duke of Lauderdail was Elected a Knight Companion of the mo≈øt noble Order of the Garter.
Dyed Sir Jonathan Dawes Sheriff and Alderman of the City of London, in the 46th. year of his Age.

Proceeded the Funeral of the Right Reverend Father in God John Co≈øin, late Lord Bi≈øhop of Durham, from Sir Gilbert Gerrads Hou≈øe in the Pell Mell near Saint James, in order to the Interment of the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop, at Bi≈øhops Auckland near Durham.

Was publi≈øhed at Paris an Ordonance,N.S. granting ≈øix months time to all Subjects of the States General of the United Provinces in France, to withdraw them≈øelves and their effects with leave and liberty to Trade and Trafficque during that time, but no longer.

Mr. Montague Emba≈ø≈øador from his Maje≈øty of Great Britain had his Audience of leave of their Maje≈øties at St. Germans, N S. and Mr. Sidney Godolphin arrived at Paris from England, in quality of Envoy Extraordinary.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty parted from St. Germans towards Nantevil, N.S. where he lodged this night.

div.head: May. 1672
div.p: Sir Thomas O≈øborne Baronet, was ≈øworn of His Maje≈øties mo≈øt Honourable Privy Coun≈øel, and took his place accordingly.
News that the Count d'E≈øtrees Vice-Admiral of France, was with the Squadron of French Ships arrived at St. Helens in the I≈øle of Wight.
There happened at Rimini ≈øo violent a ≈øtorm,N.S. as to throw to the ground all the Hou≈øes the Earth-quake, which had not long before happened there, had left ≈øtanding.
At Bologna and Ferrara mo≈øt of their Vines were ruined, and their Corn bla≈øted, to the undoing of tho≈øe Inhabitants.
Dyed at Madrid the Cardinal de Moncada, N.S. Duke of Montalto.
His Maje≈øty parted from Whitehall for Port≈ømouth, and his Royal Highne≈øs pa≈ø≈øed with his Maje≈øties Fleet by Dover we≈øtward, in order to a Conjunction with the French Squadron.
Her Maje≈øty parted from Whitehall towards Deal ‚Ä¢ .
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty arrived at Charle ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ , N.S. accompanied with the Duke of O ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ans.
The Dutch Fleet was riding in Dover road.
His Maje≈øty returned from Port≈ømouth to Whitehall.
And her Maje≈øty from Dover.
A fire at Hamb ‚Ä¢ row, which beginning in a Merchants-Hou≈øe, in ≈øome hours divers con≈øiderable Hou≈øes, where thereby con≈øumed.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty cau≈øed a review to be made of his Forces at Charleroy. N.S.
The Dutch Fleet ≈øtood for Calais, where it Anchored this night.

His Maje≈øty in Councel ordered, &c. that the Act of Parliament made in the 12th. year of his Raign, for the encouraging and increa≈øing of Shipping and Navigation, &c. ≈øhould be ≈øu≈øpended totally, &c. concerning or relating to any Ships or Ve≈ø≈øels, their Ma≈øters or Marriners, their Guns, Furniture, Tackle, &c. or to any Goods or Commodities Imported or Exported to or for Norway, or the Baltick Sea.
The Dutch Fleet was ≈øeen at the back of the Goodwin.

The States General of the United Provinces, publi≈øhed a Placaet, forbidding their own Subjects to Trade for England or France, from any Countreys what≈øoever, &c. as likewi≈øe all Strangers, though not inhabiting within the ≈øaid United Provinces, to tran≈øport any Goods or Commodities out of their Territories, for the ≈øaid Kingdoms, &c.
The Dutch Fleet was plying too and again N. N. E. off the North Forelands.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty parted from Charleroy, N.S. accompanied with the Duke of Orleans, with all his Troops, who marched in three bodies, and lodged this night at Tongres.
They continued their march towards Pirove, N.S. two leagues and a half from Tongres, where his ≈øaid Maje≈øty Encamped.
The Vi≈øcount Turrenne arrived with his Forces at Luden.
The mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King with his Army parted from Pirove, N S. and arrived at Bran ‚Ä¢ on.
The Gloce≈øter with ten of his Maje≈øties Fregats, came to an Anchor below the Gunfleet.
Several broad ≈øides were exchanged between the ≈øaid Fregats and ≈øome Dutch Ships.
His Royal Highne≈øs appeared with his Maje≈øties Fleet within fight of Dover.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty at the head of his Troops marched to grand Hach, N.S. where they Encamped upon a large Plain.

His Maje≈øty of Great Britain commanded and ordered, that the Ships, Goods, and Marchandizes of the Subjects of the States General of the United Provinces, ≈øeized in any of his Ports, before the Declaration of War, ≈øhould be forth with ≈øet at liberty, &c. and that all Dutch Merchants, or others, who neither in their Per≈øons or Goods were under this Detention, might freely depart this Kingdom, &c.
A Relea≈øement was al≈øo made by the States General of the United Provinces, of all Engli≈øh and Scotch Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øtopt in any of their Territories, before the ≈øaid Declaration of War, &c.
The French Army removed from Grand Hach, N. S. and marched to Frere.
The Inhabitants of Ma ‚Ä¢ eyck per≈øwaded to take in French Forces, in order to the fortifying thereof.
Arrived at Tongues 80. Waggons laden with Corn, for the u≈øe of the French, bought up in the parts about Vi≈øet.
His Royal Highne≈øs came with his Maje≈øties Fleet to an Anchor near the Falls.
Sir Jonathan Dawes, Sheriff and Alderman of the City of London, was honourably Interred in Saint Katherines Creed Church.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, &c. Encamped with his Army in the great Valley near Vi≈øet, N.S. all along and beyond the Meu≈øe.
His Maje≈øties Fleet under the Command of his Royal Highne≈øs, appeared at the North-≈øand head, ≈øtanding Northwards.
Tho≈øe of his Maje≈øties Fregats, under the Command of Captain Coleman in the Gloce≈øter, came to an Anchor in the Buoy of the Gunfleet.

The Dutch Fleet after the return of their Squadron out of the River, weighed out of the Gunfleet and in the Evening appeared in ≈øight of Alborough, and came to an Anchor within four or five leagues thereof.
Mae≈øtricht almo≈øt blooked up by the French.
His Maje≈øties Fregats under the Command of Captain Coleman, ≈øet Sail in order to a Conjunction with his Maje≈øties Fleet.
His Maje≈øties Fleet under the Command of his Royal Highne≈øs, got ≈øight of the Dutch Fleet, about eight leagues E. S. E. of the Gunfleet.
His Maje≈øties Fleet under the command of his Royal Highne≈øs appeared this Evening, ≈øtanding in for Southwould Bay, and came to an Anchor about four leagues thereof.
The Sluces at Lillo were opened,N.S. and all the Polders ≈øet under water, as were likewi≈øe the Lowlands about Bergen-op-Zoom.

A Proclamation, that it ≈øhould be lawful to and for his Maje≈øties Subjects, as well Merchants as others, to ≈øet out Ships to Sea, and to carry on their Trade and Commerce, as fully, &c. as they could or might have done, if no re≈øtraint or imbargo formerly had been made, &c. and that all pa≈ø≈øes and protections for Ships and Marriners formerly granted, ≈øhould be in full force and effect.
Arrived at Copenhagen his Grace the Duke of Richmond, N.S. Extraordinary Emba≈ø≈øador from his Maje≈øty of Great Britain.
A Bridge over the Rhyne was wholly fini≈øhed,N.S. at or about Key≈øarwaert, where the French Army quickly after pa≈ø≈øed over.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty and his whole Army decamped from Vi≈øet, N.S. and pa≈ø≈øing the Meu≈øe over a Bridge of Boats, encamped about half a league from Vi≈øet afore≈øaid.
The Bi≈øhop of Liege came to complement his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty upon his arrival in tho≈øe parts.N. S.
A ≈øuddain and violent fire broke out in the hou≈øe of a Tobacco and Strong-water ≈øeller, at the Iron gate near the Tower, doing con≈øiderable mi≈øchief.
News that at Zant, Zeffalonia, and Corfu, the Inhabitants were in ≈øo great want of Corn, that ≈øeveral men did daily ≈øell them≈øelves to the Galleys, only to have a ≈ømall ≈øu≈øtenance for life.
A ≈øharp Sea-fight happened towards Southwould, Laytoff, &c. between his Maje≈øties Fleet, under the Command of his Royal Highne≈øs, and the Dutch, in which the Royal James was burnt.

Dyed Sir John Trevor, one of his Maje≈øties principal Secreraries of State, and one of his mo≈øt honourable Privy Councel, in the
fourty ≈øeventh year of his Age.

Being the great Anniver≈øary of his Maje≈øties Birth and happy Re≈øtoration, was Celebrated at London, with great demon≈øtrations of publick joy, &c. a new Conduit of a noble and beautiful Structure being opened in the Stocks Market Place, near Lumbard ≈øtreet, running Claret for divers hours, &c. erected at the ≈øole charge of Sir Robert Viner, &c.
'Twas al≈øo Celebrated at Lyn, with great demon≈øtrations of publick joy.
The Right Honourable Henry, Marquis of Worce≈øter, the Earl of St. Albans, and the Earl of Bedford, were Elected Knights Companions of the mo≈øt noble Order of the Garter.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty having with his Army pa≈ø≈øed the Rhyne at Key≈øerweart, arrived at Holtzen, a ≈ømall place not far from Nuis, where his Maje≈øty was met by the Elector of Cologne.

div.head: Iune.
div.p: His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty with his Army marched towards Rhyneberg.
Was honourably interred Sir John Trevor at St. Bartholomews in Smithfield.
His Maje≈øties Fleet, under the command of his Royal Highne≈øs, came to an Anchor in Sole Bay.
The Fleet weighed again and ≈øtood to Sea.
The Dutche≈øs d'Enguine was brought to Bed of a Son at Saint Germanes. N.S.

His Grace the Duke of Lauderdale, by a Proxy, the right honourable Henry Marquis of VVorce≈øter, the Earl of St. Albans, and the Earl of Bedford, were en≈øtalled at VVin≈øor Knights of the mo≈øt noble Order of the Garter.
Was Interred in the Quire of Roche≈øter Mon≈øieur Rabiniere tres le Bos, Reer-Admiral of the French Squadron, who dyed at Chattam of the wounds he had received in the late Engagement.

Great troubles began to ≈øeize upon the people of the United Provinces, by the appearance of the French Armies, who Be≈øieging Rhyneberg, Or≈øoy, VVe≈øel, and Burick, were quickly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of them.

Fell a violent Rain at Madrid with much Thunder,N.S. which broke down a part of the Tower of the Covent of the Holy Trinity; The Lightning ≈øcorched one of the Fathers, and killed three men without the Gates.
Arrived a Bode or Me≈ø≈øenger (at Harwich) of the States General of the United Provinces, on his way to the Dutch Emba≈ø≈øador at London.
Arrived at Edinbergh his Grace the Duke of Lauderdale, his Maje≈øties High Commi≈ø≈øioner of Scotland.
The body of the Earl of Sandwich was di≈øcovered floating on the Sea, by one of his Maje≈øties Ketches, and brought up to Harwich.

His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øties Armies appearing before Rees, quickly made that and Emmerick their own; as the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter did Doetechem, Groll, and Borkelo, after the taking of Rees and Emmerick the French proceeded to Skenk≈øcance of the Rhyne, in order
to a pa≈ø≈øing the River about Tolhuys.
His Maje≈øty gave order for the publi≈øhing of his Gracious Declaration, towards all ≈øuch Subjects of the Low Countreys, as ≈øhould come into his Kingdom, &c.
His Grace the Duke of Richmond, his Maje≈øties extraordinary Emba≈ø≈øador to the Crown of Deumark, made his publick Entry at Copenhagen.
A Proclamation, forewarning and ≈øtraitly commanding all his Maje≈øties Subjects, &c. not by writing or ≈øpeaking, to utter or publi≈øh any fal≈øe news or reports.
At mid-night her Maje≈øty of France was brought to Bed of a young Prince.N.S.
A ≈øolemn Proce≈ø≈øion at Paris, on occa≈øion of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øties good ≈øucce≈øs again≈øt the Dutch. N.S.
A tumult at the Hague, the people throwing ≈øtones at the hou≈øe of the Heer van Mombas. N.S.
Bonfires at Paris, and other demon≈øtrations of publick joy,N.S. for the birth of the young Prince.
The right honourable Henry, Earl of Arlington, elected a Knight Companion of the mo≈øt noble order of the Garter.

News that the French had pa≈ø≈øed the Rhyne into the Betuwe, that Utrecht had yielded to his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, and that the French Troops were advanced as far as Amersford, and that the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter had taken Swoll and Breefort, the French Knotzenbergh, and that Culenbergh, Tiel, Buren, &c. had yielded to the French, that Rave≈øtine was demoli≈øhed by them, and that Scenck≈øcance, and Arnhem were al≈øo taken, & that the common people began to be very rumultuous at Middlebourgh; and that at Am≈øterdam they were lately in danger of being plundered by the commonalty, and that the Countrey there abouts, as al≈øo at Dort, &c. was ≈øet under water for ≈øome leagues together, to hinder the approach of the French; as al≈øo at Rotterdam, Leyden, and Delf, that the common people were very unruly and tumultuous.
The two young Counts Tillions two brothers,N.S. were A≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinated at Mons by ≈øeven or eight Spaniards, as they were coming out of the Church.
The Trenches were opened before Daesburgh. N S.

A great tumult at Dort among≈øt the Inhabitants,N.S. in which the people would have been killing and plundering their Burgema≈øter, and other chief Officers of the Town, had not the Lords pre≈øently declared his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange their Governour and Stadtholder.

His Grace the Duke of Bucks, the right honourable the Earl of Arlington, the Earl of Shaftsbury, and the Lord Clifford went to the Deputies of the States General of the United Provinces at Hampton Court.
Doesburgh yielded to the French.
N.S.The Count Conning≈ømark, Emba≈ø≈øador Extraordinary from the Crown of Sweden, had Audience of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty.
The right honourable the Earl of Arlington, was at Wind≈øor, by a Proxy, en≈øtalled Knight of the mo≈øt noble Order of the Garter.
His Grace the Duke of Bucks, and the right honourable the Earl of Arlington, began their journey for Holland, as his Maje≈øties extraordinary Emba≈ø≈øadors and Plenipotentiaries.
Their Excellencies parted in the Katherine and Henrietta Yachts from the Buoy in the Nore.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty had advice of the taking of Deventer, N.S. and that Swoll, Campen, Elborough, Arderwick Hatten, Ha≈ø≈øelt, and Ommen, &c. had yielded upon ≈øummons.
His Maje≈øty had an account of the taking al≈øo of the Forts of Voorne and St. Andre.
His Grace the Duke of Bucks, and the right honourable the Earl of Arlington arrived at the Maes, Landed at Mae≈øland Sluice, and in the evening arrived at the Hague.
The Bi≈øhop of Strasburgh arrived at the French Camp,N.S. and had Audience of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King.

The Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter arrived there,N.S. had (after his Maje≈øty had had ≈øome conference with him) a Cro≈øs of Diamonds, of very great value, pre≈øented unto him by his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, and ≈øo returned to his Army.
The Baron de Metemiche, Envoy from the Elector of Treves, had likewi≈øe Audience of the ≈øaid King.
And this night came news to his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, of the ≈øurrender of Zutphen.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty parted from Biloni towards Amerongen. N. S.
His ≈øaid Maje≈øty arrived at Amerongen. N.S.
The Sieur de Groot arrived in the French Camp with ample power, &c. from the States General of the United Provinces.
Dyed not far from Rome Cardinal Franci≈øco Mancini, N.S. in the 66. year of his age, and 15th. of his Cardinalato.
His Royal Highne≈øs with his Maje≈øties Fleet, came to an Anchor off of Harwich.
Set Sail for the Coa≈øt of Holland.
At Dort his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, N.S. by an Act was made Stadt-holder.
His Maje≈øties Fleet in the evening appeared within ≈øix leagues of the Brill.

div.head: Iuly.
div.p: The States of Holland concluded, that the perpetual Edict of their never admitting of a Stadt-holder, ≈øhould cea≈øe, &c.
Grave yielded to the French.
The States of Zealand made his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, Stadtholder of that Province, &c.
His Highne≈øs was al≈øo made Stadtholder of Holland quickly after, and declared Stadt-holder at Am≈øterdam.
The body of the Earl of Sandwich, (which was taken up at Sea) was magnificently Interred in King Henry the 7th's Chappel, in the Vault on the North ≈øide of the Quire.
Henry Coventry E≈øq ≈øworn into the place of his Maje≈øties principal Secretary of State, in the room of Sir John Trevor decea≈øed.

Sworn al≈øo together with Sir Robert Long Knight and Baronet,
of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt honourable Privy Councel, and took their places accordingly.
Their Excellencies the Duke of Buckingham, and the Earl of Arlington, arrived at Utrecht from the Hague.
Had their publick Audience of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty in his quarters in the Camp.
Arrived at Utrecht the Vi≈øcount Hallifax, Envoy extraordinary from his Maje≈øty of Great Britain.
Had his Audience of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King in his Camp.N.S.
Nimmegen taken by the French.

The Commonalty at Rotterdam plundered the hou≈øe of one of their Magi≈øtrates, and beat out the windows of another, and ≈øeveral Articles were pre≈øented by the Citizens to the Burgerma≈øters and common Councel of the ≈øame, &c. relating to the Prince of Orange.
The Commi≈ø≈øion of Stadtholder, was delivered at the Hague to his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange. N.S.

His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty with his whole Army,N.S. decamped from Zey≈øt, and took his way towards Boi≈øleduck by the way of Arnehem, Nimmegen, &c. leaving the Duke of Luxemburgh, with a con≈øiderable Force in the Province of Utrecht, which Province was now wholly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the French.
The French Army Encamped half a mile from Rhenen. N.S.
Under the Walls of Arnehem.
N.S.Happened at Venice a violent ≈øtorm with Thunder and Hail, of an extraordinary bigne≈øs.N.S.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty pa≈ø≈øed over with his Army at two or three ≈øeveral places of the Rhyne, N.S. and Encamped within half a league of Nimmegen.
Covoerden ≈øurrendred to the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter. N.S.
Arrived at Vienna the Prince d'Anhalt from Berlin, N.S. with full power to conclude a Treaty with the Emperor and the Elector of Brandenburgh, for the defence of the Empire.

Certain news of the continuation of the difference between the Duke of Savoy, and the States of Genoua, a War being begun between them ≈øome time before. The Duke of Savoy's Troops, taking (or attempting upon) Piev√©.
A Ve≈ø≈øel arrived at Harwich from his Maje≈øties Fleet, giving an account that the ≈øaid Fleet was in a good condition upon the Coa≈øt of Holland, and that his Royal Highne≈øs was in perfect health.
The Sieur Pelnitz arrived at the Hague, N.S. on the part of the Elector of Brandenburgh.
The Engli≈øh Emba≈ø≈øadors and Plenipotentiaries lodged at Nimmegen.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty ≈øaw his Army pa≈øs the Waal, N.S. and than it marched to Grave.
The Army repo≈øed it ≈øelf at Grave. N.S.
The Army removed two leagues further,N.S. to a place called Boxtel.
Crevecoeur taken by the French.
The Engli≈øh Emba≈ø≈øadors and Plenipotentiaries,N.S. parted from the French Camp at Boxtel towards Antwerp, and lodged at Turnhault.
They arrived at Antwerp. N.S.

Was honourably Interred in the Pari≈øh Church of Bum≈øtead of the Tower in E≈ø≈øex, that mo≈øt accompli≈øhed and aged Gentleman, Sir Thomas Bendi≈øh Baronet, formerly for very many years together Emba≈ø≈øador in Turky.
Bommel ≈øurrendred to the French. N.S.
His Maje≈øties Plenipotentiaries, the Duke of Bucks, the Earl of Arlington, and the Lord Vi≈øcount Hallifax returned to Whitehall.
His Maje≈øty conferred the honour of Knighthood upon Henry Ford E≈øq Secretary to the Earl of E≈ø≈øex, as likewi≈øe on Captain John Edgeworth.
The Earl of E≈ø≈øex, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, began his journey towards that Kingdom.
The Cambridge and Bri≈øtol Frigats, met the Dutch East-India Fleet, ten or twelve leagues to the We≈øt-ward of Heylige Landt, where they hotly engaged them.

A Proclamation that no per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever, ≈øhould import, or cau≈øe to be imported into England, VVales, or Barwick upon Tweed, any kind or ≈øort of Painted Earthen Wares, what≈øoever, except tho≈øe of China, and ≈øtone Bottles, and Jugs, &c. upon pain of being grieviou≈øly fined, &c.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty parted from the Camp at Boxtel, N.S. for the Abbey of Postel, parted from thence towards Berningnen, proceeded to Lummen, where he lodged this night.
The Sieur Mombas made his e≈øcape out of Pri≈øon at the Hague. N.S.
Was brought to the Hague Pri≈øoner from Dort, the Sieur de Wit, Ruwaert van Putten.
News that Groningen was clo≈øe Be≈øieged by the Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter.
His mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty returned to St. Germanes. N.S.

div.head: Augu≈øt.
div.p: Was concluded the Treaty for the publick ≈øecurity,N.S. and general Defence of the Empire.
The Earl of Eu≈øton was married to the onely Daughter of the Earl of Arlington.
The Sieur Pelnitz, Envoy from the Elector of Brandenburgh, N.S. took his leave of the States General of the United Provinces, in order to his return home.
Then Pen≈øionary de Wit was in the A≈ø≈øembly of the States of Holland, N.S. endeavouring to clear him≈øelf of ≈øeveral matters whereof he ≈øtood accu≈øed.
The Dutch Fleet Northward of the Maes.
The Earl of E≈ø≈øex, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, arrived at Dunlary, and about three in the afternoon arrived at Dublin.
Happened a great di≈øturbance at Middleburgh, N.S. between the Magi≈øtrates and Burghers, &c.
Te Deum was ≈øung in the Churches at Genoua, N.S. for the Victory their Forces had lately obtained over tho≈øe of the Duke of Savoy at Ca≈øtello Vecchio.
Mae≈øtricht more then ever blocked up by the French, by their lying quartered round about it.
Was exchanged with the French Emba≈ø≈øador at London, the Ratification of the Treaty concluded by his Maje≈øties late Plenipotentiaries in the French Camp, &c.

The French pa≈ø≈øed on both ≈øides the River,N.S. near the Fort of Navaigne, with a very con≈øiderable Army towards Mae≈øtricht, and quickly after as it were quite ≈øurrounded Mae≈øtricht, and drew a line of Circumvalation between on Ravens Hou≈øe, and a ≈ømall Village called Scharen, to defend them≈øelves again≈øt the Sallyes of that Garrizon.
News of Oneglia's ≈øurrender to the Genoue≈øes.
A Proclamation, touching half pence and farthings, &c.
Great di≈øorders at Delf.

N.S.Mr. Cornelis de VVit, ancient Burgherma≈øter of the Town of Dort, N.S. and Ruward of the Lands of Putten, was Sentenced by the Court of Holland and We≈øt-Frie≈øland, to be bani≈øhed out of tho≈øe Provinces, and to loo≈øe all his Dignities and Imployments po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by him, &c.

He and his Brother the Pen≈øionary de Wit killed by the people at the Hague, in a mo≈øt notorious manner, and their dead bodies hanged upon a Gallows by the heels, being u≈øed in ≈øuch manner as ≈øcarce the like hath ever been heard off.

Happened at Madrid in the Placa Mayor a very great fire,N.S. which in few hours burnt to the ground all the Pile of Buildings, called the Planadera, with many other dwellings, &c. containing as was ≈øuppo≈øed 2000. Families, whereof ≈øome were killed and burnt, and others hurt in quenching of the fire.
Certain news that the Heer de Groot was with drawn, &c. al≈øo that Sieur Mombas and he was at Cologne.

A general Rendez-vous of the Emperial Forces at Egra in Bohemia, N.S. who quickly after marched from thence towards Halber≈øtadt, in order to a Conjunction with the Brandenburgh Forces, &c. Arrived there.
Her Grace the Dutche≈øs of Monmouth, was brought to Bed of a Son.

Several Articles were put up upon the Exchange at Am≈øterdam, N.S. of a menacing nature, and the people much di≈ø≈øatisfied, urging for a further reformation in the Magi≈øtracy, in imitation of Rotterdam and Delf.
The Heer Fagel elected Pen≈øionary of Holland.
The Turks invade the Ukrain.
Was beheaded in the Dutch Army Colonel d'O≈ø≈øery, N.S. late Governour of Rhynebergh.
The Turks take Cominiec.
The Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter rai≈øed his Siege at Groningen.
The Dutch Fleet arrived again before Shoonevelt.
The French Army, which had for ≈øome time been encamped before Mae≈øtricht, N.S. broke up from thence and marched towards the Rhyne.

div.head: September.
div.p: Colonel Zouteland Pri≈øoner at the Hague, N. S. made his e≈øcape out of Pri≈øon, but was retaken.
News that the Burghers at the Brill had di≈øplaced all their old Magi≈øtrates.
Blockzeil retaken by the Dutch.
Happened a Rencounter between the Duke of Luxemburgh's Forces,N.S. and the Dutch about Woerden.
The Burghers at Delf drove their Magi≈øtrates from the Town-hou≈øe.N.S.
The Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter returned with his Forces into VVe≈øtphalia.
At Middleburgh the Soulders under the command of Captain Soutland, N.S. came in an unruly manner to the States, demanding their Arrears.
Charles Earl of Dunca≈øter, his Grace the Duke of Monmouth's ≈øon was Chri≈øtned by his Grace the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury.
Poland much di≈øturbed and alarmed at the approach of the Grand Seignours Forces, now having entred into tho≈øe parts, acting vigorou≈øly again≈øt that Kingdom.
A great di≈øturbance at Am≈øterdam, N. S. where the Commonalty, would have been plundring Lieutenant Admiral de Ruyters Hou≈øe.
Arrived at Genoua Mon≈øieur Gaumont, N.S. the French Envoy.
He had private Audience of the Senate there,N.S. making ≈øome Propo≈øitions, in order to a Peace between that State and the Duke of Savoy.
Mon≈øieur Turenne pa≈ø≈øed the Rhyne about We≈øel with his whole Army,N.S. in order to his attending the coming down of the Imperial and Brandenburgh Forces.
His Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange wrote a Letter unto the Burghers of Am≈øterdam, N.S. in order to their de≈øire in their changing of their Magi≈øtrates.
The Heer Kievit made Pen≈øionary of Rotterdam, in the place of the Heer de Groot.
Arrived at Halber≈øtadt General Montecuculi, N.S. having left his Troops at Mulhau≈øen.
The Dutch Fleet off of Zealand, and many of their great Ships ordered to be laid up for this Winter.N. S.
A great fire in Saint Bernards Cloy≈øter at Antwerp. N.S.
His Maje≈øty ordered his Proclamation to be publi≈øhed for the proroguing of the Parliament, from October 30. to the 4th. of February next.
His Royal Highne≈øs arrived at the Court from the Fleet.
Certain news, that many of the Dutch great Ships and men of War were gone in.
The Elector of Brandenburgh took up his own Quarters in the Engli≈øh Mona≈øtry at Lamb≈øping. N.S.
Several Hor≈øe and Foot of the Brandenburgh Forces arrived at Leeuwen. N.S.
Count Montecuculi left the Brandenburgh Court, and went to the Imperial Army.
The Imperial Army pa≈ø≈øed by Ey≈øenach, N.S. and took up their chief quarter at Herle≈øhau≈øen.
They came to Heringen.
N.S.To Kirckha≈ø≈øel a league from Heunfeldt.
The Imperial and Brandenburgh Troops at or about Heuxter, and made towards Francford.
Five Felons were executed at Durham, one of whom John U≈øard, at the place of Execution, confe≈ø≈øed he was in the plot in the year 1663. ≈øhewing his hearty ≈øorrow and penitence for the ≈øame.
Was a ≈øharp di≈øpute at the Ble≈ø≈øerbrugh, N.S. between Steenwick and Wolviga, between a party of the Dutch, and ≈øome French and Cologne Troops.
Sir Robert Han≈øon was cho≈øen to be Lord Mayor of the City of London, for the en≈øuing year.
Pritchard and James Smith E≈øq ≈øworn Sheriffs of London and Middle≈øex.
